questions.question: Which of the following best describes a Java servlet?
answers: A server-side Java program that dynamically processes requests and generates dynamic web pages.
A client-side Java program that runs in a web browser.
A Java program that handles database operations on the server-side.
A Java program that compiles HTML files into executable code.

questions.question: What is the main function of a Java servlet container?
answers: To manage client-side Java programs.
To compile JSP files into servlets.
To manage the lifecycle of servlets and handle requests from clients.
To execute SQL queries for servlets.

questions.question: Which file extension is typically used for JavaServer Pages (JSP) files?
answers: .jspf
.js
.jsp
.java

questions.question: What is a session in the context of Java servlets?
answers: A method in a Java class.
An object that persists across multiple client requests.
A container for servlet classes.
A built-in Java package for handling HTTP requests.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a phase in the lifecycle of a servlet?
answers: Initialization
Service
Destruction
Validation

questions.question: What is the purpose of the <jsp:include> action in JSP?
answers: To include a Java class in a JSP file.
To include another JSP file in the current JSP file.
To include a CSS file in a JSP file.
To include a JavaScript file in a JSP file.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about servlet thread safety?
answers: Servlets are inherently thread-safe.
Servlets are inherently not thread-safe.
Servlets may or may not be thread-safe depending on implementation.
Servlets cannot be accessed concurrently.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the web.xml file in a Java web application?
answers: To store session data.
To define servlet mappings and configurations.
To define HTML layout templates.
To store user authentication credentials.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about JSP directives?
answers: They are used to define variables within JSP files.
They are used to import Java classes into JSP files.
They are used to declare custom tag libraries.
They are used to define CSS styles in JSP files.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the forward() method in a servlet?
answers: To redirect the client to another URL.
To forward the request and response objects to another servlet or JSP.
To include another servlet or JSP in the current servlet.
To send data from the server to the client.
